sn11.1:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn11.1:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
sn11.1:2.1: “Once upon a time, mendicants, the demons marched against the gods.
sn11.1:2.2: Then Sakka, lord of gods, addressed the god Suvīra,
sn11.1:2.3: ‘Dear Suvīra, the demons march against the gods!
sn11.1:2.4: Go, and march against the demons!’
sn11.1:2.5: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Suvīra. But he fell into negligence.
sn11.1:2.6: For a second time Sakka addressed Suvīra,
sn11.1:2.7: ‘Dear Suvīra, the demons march against the gods!
sn11.1:2.8: Go, and march against the demons!’
sn11.1:2.9: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Suvīra. But for a second time he fell into negligence.
sn11.1:2.10: For a third time Sakka addressed Suvīra,
sn11.1:2.11: ‘Dear Suvīra, the demons march against the gods!
sn11.1:2.12: Go, and march against the demons!’
sn11.1:2.13: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Suvīra. But for a third time he fell into negligence.
sn11.1:2.14: Then Sakka addressed the god Suvīra in verse:
sn11.1:3.3: without working for it or trying hard—
sn11.1:4.1: ‘That a lazy man who does no work,
sn11.1:5.2: where a lazy man who does no work
sn11.1:6.2: that we might find the happiness
sn11.1:7.2: who can can live happily without working,
sn11.1:7.3: that surely would be extinguishment’s path!
sn11.1:8.1: So, mendicants, even Sakka, lord of gods—while living off of the fruit of his good and bad deeds, and ruling as sovereign lord over these gods of the Thirty-Three—will speak in praise of initiative and energy.
sn11.1:8.2: But since you have gone forth in such a well explained teaching and training, it would be truly beautiful for you to try hard, strive, and make an effort to attain the unattained, achieve the unachieved, and realize the unrealized!”
